Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: QUEST: An Integrated Query and Event System on Noisy Streams and Tables

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sequence and order are prevalent in data. In particular, time, as often perceived as the "fourth dimension", plays a pivotal role in data streams as well as in stored time series data. The ability to define events, detect and query complex events over noisy sequence data is a much needed addition to the standard data management systems and SQL. This is because complex event detection is about discovering the correlation and co-occurrence of many tuples in the same relation - different from the cursor model in SQL, and because it is sensitive to sequence errors. The goal of this research is to tightly integrate SQL queries and complex event detection over noisy streams and stored tables in a high-performing system. Specific techniques include: (1) Using a query suite to encapsulate the interactions between SQL queries and complex event detection, and proposing a comprehensive semantics for complex events; (2) Incorporating correlated error models into a novel complex event matching algorithm; (3) Designing more efficient algorithms that only get the top-k highest probability matching paths, as well as algorithms that handle other variants of semantics; and (4) Devising several indexing mechanisms for stored sequence tables, and performing overall system optimization for both streams and tables.

The QUEST project has applications in dietary and exercise monitoring/analysis, ECG monitoring, shopping behavior study, security monitoring, and travel pattern discovery, among many others. These applications play a key role in the nation's economy (business intelligence), health, and security. The project greatly enriches the course contents of the undergraduate directed research course in addition to a new graduate course. Further information on the project can be found on the project web page:
http://www.cs.uml.edu/~ge/projects/quest/ .

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have performed some interesting research and advanced the state-of-the-art of complex event processing in fast real-time data streams, especially when the data is noisy and uncertain. First, we studied complex event matching in data streams when the data is noisy and can be modeled by probability distributions. In our SIGMOD’13 paper, we propose a new approach that efficiently does the matching based on an error model. In particular, our algorithms are based on the realistic Markov chain error model, and report all matching paths to trace relevant basic events that trigger the matching. We also devise algorithms to efficiently return only top-k matching paths, and to handle negations in an extended regular expression.

Second, in our ICDE’15 paper, we observe that many applications require parallel interleaving event matching. We propose the query semantics. One of our algorithmic optimizations is called an automaton sketch. We present a randomized algorithm that continuously determines the shape of the sketch so as to optimize the savings. Using Markov chain theory, we analyze that the execution trace of our algorithm forms a Markov chain. We prove that this chain has a stationary distribution that basically converges to the optimal sketch configuration. Furthermore, using the Markov chain coupling theory, we show that this convergence is also very fast.

Third, many data streams in applications are naturally associated with a structure. We have explored some data stream topics in the so-called graph streams. Complex event processing in graph streams needs a different semantics and must encode both timing constraints among basic events and graph structure constraints on event edges. In our VLDB’15 paper, we first propose the pattern query semantics. Then we propose a baseline algorithm and two advanced algorithms – the first one uses number theory to build a signature for real-time fast matching, while the second one is based on edge coloring for which an amortized analysis shows its efficiency.

Third, we tackle the problem of finding irregular/outlier events in sequence data. Certain events and activities often have some patterns within a time unit. It is useful to find out the model of such regularity, and to identify irregular or unusual events when they happen. In our ICDE’16 paper, we propose an algorithmic framework based on message passing and event hierarchies to build a regular model, which can be easily parallelized. We also propose a method that returns the regularity of all events in a sequence, which is shown to be very effective in experiments.

Fourth, we study the problem of dynamically querying the top-k most frequent (“hot”) items in a past window of any size. In our ICDE’17 paper, we devise a randomized algorithm. The idea is to let each item in the stream performs an independent action—choosing a random “level” from a distribution, such that some aggregate value grouped by each distinct item is probabilistically proportional to the frequency of that item. We rigorously prove the time and space complexity, as well as the accuracy of our algorithm.

Fifth, we observe that data acquisition in streams is not free—it consumes either monetary cost or computing resource. On the other hand, value changes are gradual and incremental. Thus, it is sometimes sufficient to use the old version of data for query processing, without losing much accuracy in the results. There is a fine balance and tradeoff on when to acquire new data for an entity, and when to live with the old-version data to answer a query. In our VLDB’17 paper, we study this intriguing problem with a novel use of a machine learning technique called reinforcement learning. Our work finds applications in data caching too.

Finally, we study “approximate match” in complex event processing (ACEP), in that we allow a limited number of events in the pattern to be totally unmatched in the data, and the match result is still meaningful. In our VLDB’17 paper, we first propose an algorithm for ACEP. Then we devise a learning approach to learn from the behavior of past ACEP query processing, so as to judiciously determine the order of processing intermediate match nodes (states) to maximize the number of full-matches found, given some constraints on computing resources (i.e., CPU cannot keep up with the real-time data stream).

The ideas studied in this project have broad applications in this big data era, including dynamic traffic routing, DNA and protein sequence pattern matching, ECG monitoring, emergency responses, business intelligence based on smartphones and sensors, and social network streams. The research results from this project are incorporated in two courses the PI is teaching. Graduate and undergraduate students have received valuable training in this project, including three Ph.D. students whose theses are based on the contents from this project. Finally, we have outreach activities with researchers and students from other disciplines.


Last Modified: 10/11/2017
Modified by: Tingjian Ge

First, we studied complex event matching in data streams when the data is noisy and can be modeled by probability distributions. Third, we tackle the problem of finding irregular/outlier events in sequence data. Certain events and activities often have some patterns within a time unit.
